results.title: V160777 (Chocos)
results.creator_credit: Bill Goodes, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When he signed up as a conscript, Bill Goodes was given the number V160777 and the label Choco. He knew it was given to the conscripts that, like him, fought in New Guinea, but he had no idea what it meant, though he did sense the connotation was negative. He reflects on how he fought like any other soldier, for three years without a break. In New Guinea, he was just like everyone else. But when he returned to Australia to take up life as a dairy farmer, he soon realised that some people just saw him as a Choco. For Bill, none of this has detracted from his contribution to the war effort.

results.title: Doing it our way, according to our culture
results.creator_credit: Frances Gallagher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Growing up in a mission, Frances Gallagher had disjointed access to her own culture and found it hard to navigate the world outside. By looking into her past, and through her years of community work, Frances sends a strong message of the importance of empowerment and self-determination. Essentially, a community is much stronger when they can manage their own affairs, their way and according to their culture and beliefs.

results.title: Growing up on Cummera
results.creator_credit: May Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: May is a Yorta Yorta woman who grew up on Cummera Gunja mission. She warmly reflects on her days there, swimming and listening the the elders tell their stories. Moved away from her community, she experienced racism and prejudice but from those experiences learnt to overcome the boundries that others set up for her. She has since committed to a lifetime of learning and teaching and linking children and family back to their communities.

results.title: Come on Bushy
results.creator_credit: Bill Bush, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bill Bush joined the army for a bit of adventure and to escape troubles at home. He fought in Korea, where his skills as a paramedic were also utilised. He continued this work into civilian life. With a mantra of doing what you were told, without complaint, Bill ultimately leads a happy life doing what he loves.

results.title: Rwanda
results.creator_credit: Joanne Harding, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Joanne Harding was sent to Rwanda as part of the Australian Defence Force medical Support Force. She focuses on the part of her experience that affected her the most, the eyes of the children. She describes their eyes as pools of nothingness as they begin to accept war as part of their everyday life. In turn, Joanne begins to question the effectiveness of her role and that of the United Nations in bringing peace to this wartorn country.

results.title: Black people power
results.creator_credit: Kelvin Onus-King, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Onus-King learnt that ‘you only get what you want when you fight for it’ and he learnt this in more ways than one over the years. He takes us back through the history of Indigenous activists in Fitzroy and how this area was a hot bed of political activity as he was growing up. He later became strongly involved in the fight for better conditions and has taken that fight across Australia.

results.title: Growing up in Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marlene (Scerri) Young gives us a picture of what it was like to grow up in Fitzroy in the 1950s. She lovingly tells of the closeness to her extended family, the friends coming to stay over and the strong sense of community, especially the Christmas parades down Smith Street.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Sense of guilt
results.creator_credit: Robert English, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A psychological portrait of a man who’s life has been marred by the horrors of war, as seen by his son. The English family were aware that when George English came back to Australia after the war he was a changed man but it wasn’t until son Robert volunteered to go to Vietnam that feelings George couldn’t disguise any longer came to the fore. In telling his story of his voyage back to Australia and their detour through Java. it became clear that George had been hiding the profound sense of guilt about surviving the war when many of his colleagues didn’t.

results.title: Victimised, Assimalised, Correctionalised
results.creator_credit: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. His incarceration didn’t end there and for much of his adult life Howard was a target for police and he was often locked up at the slightest provocation. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.

results.title: Dots and dashes
results.creator_credit: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Catching mumps just before his 18th birthday prevented Kevin Coughlin from joining the RAAF during the second World War. But thanks to his connections, he was able to get work as a Wireless Telegraphist. In the end, Kevin ended up with skills that made him unique. Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
